awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this program is to provide a combination of financial support, academic enrichment, mentoring, professional development resources, and leadership preparation to twenty-six talented students with financial need so that they can navigate successfully through their undergraduate years in science or mathematics at the institution. To support student achievement at the highest academic level, scholarship recipients are embedded in a mentoring network of peers, near peers, faculty, professional scientists and alumni who are further advanced on the academic pathway. The financial support relieves talented students with financial need of the obligation to work and take out loans while they make their way through a first class education in the mathematical or physical sciences to graduate school or the scientific workforce.

Intellectual Merit:

This project opens the door for academically talented students from diverse backgrounds with demonstrated financial need to key fields of modern science. By focusing on potential for leadership and success, the program encourages the scholarship recipients to envision, plan for, and prepare for graduate school or productive and competitive careers in the scientific workforce. Priority is being given to supporting the preparation and advancement of students with interest, academic merit, and indicators of determination to succeed in the fields of Astronomy, Chemistry, Geology, Geophysics, Earth and Planetary Science, Mathematics, Applied Mathematics, Physics, and Statistics. During the freshman and sophomore years, scholars become members of and benefit directly from the formal networked community of scientists. Leadership and talent development opportunities are being introduced during the junior and senior years.

Broader Impacts:

The project prioritizes the recruitment and retention of diversity students, using the legal California post-Proposition 209 definition to include historically underrepresented minorities, women, students with disabilities, and students who are the first generation in their families to go to college. To achieve this, the project works closely with the Office of Admissions and the Financial Aid Office to identify eligible students who also increase diversity in the mathematical and physical sciences. The project team then engages in active partnership with programs that focus on the recruitment and advancement of students from groups underrepresented in science and are administered by the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Diversity and Education Center. These include the Berkeley Science Network and the NSF-Berkeley Science Connections, both of which are designed to facilitate the advancement of underrepresented minorities in the mathematical, physical and computer sciences from high school through post-doctoral levels; The Compass Project, which fosters an inclusive community in the physical sciences at the undergraduate level; and the Society for Women in the Physical Sciences, a university supported program run by female graduate students in Physics, Astronomy, Earth and Planetary Sciences and Biophysics, whose goals are to encourage women and minorities to study the physical sciences and to create a friendly and supportive environment in these departments for all students.

por.por_cntn:
GOALS

1. Increase retention in the mathematical and physical sciences (MPS) of academically talented undergraduates with interest in these fields and demonstrated financial need, including those who enter without stating an intended major in the freshman and sophomore years. Provide financial support in the amount of $5,000 per year to two cohorts of 13 students each, and support them to completion of their bachelor's degrees.

2. Increase retention of undergraduates from historically underrepresented groups in the MPS majors ?including underrepresented minorities (URM), first generation college students, women, students with disabilities, and others who meet the Proposition-209 diversity definition.

3. Provide Berkeley Science Network-Leadership Program (BSN-LP) participants with a comprehensive set of professional development opportunities and academic resources to enhance their success. Integrate BSN-LP students into the Berkeley Science Network's (BSN) structured program in order to maximize the likelihood of their advancement into graduate training and career positions where they can assume leadership roles. Engage scholars in BSN, a newly established academically embedded social network. In their junior and senior years, emphasize leadership coaching and skill building to assist the scholars in setting high goals and achieving them.

4. Improve student support programs by infusing into them effective, trained student leaders who also represent the diversity of California's communities.

OVERVIEW

During the entire BSN-LP grant period 2014-2021, 51 scholars were supported. Of those supported, 40 are URM students and 11 are non-URM students. 

ACADEMIC MERIT

In support of the program's goals, during the grant period of 2014-2021, BSN-LP accomplished the following.

Scholarships to Support Retention in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) 

In addition to the scholarships offered during the academic year, BSN-LP scholars were offered summer support when needed to enable their participation in research and academic enrichment activities. This was especially important during 2020-21 as students had been completing course work remotely and had few opportunities to engage in in-person academic activities. 

Mentoring for Academic Advancement  

To encourage undergraduate students' retention and advancement in STEM generally, and MPS in particular, scholars were mentored by faculty, staff, and graduate students. At the end of each semester, program staff and affiliated faculty assessed student progress, developed retention and advancement plans for students when needed, and supported scholars in accessing the resources that would support these plans. One-to-one mentor meetings were held with BSN-LP students to address each student's specific and unique needs. The focus of the meetings was on academic advancement, career plans, and financial security. 

Networking and Professional Development to Increase Connections to STEM Community

BSN-LP students enjoyed opportunities to engage in a vibrant community of scientists. This community offered connections to near-peers, faculty, and expert staff, leadership workshops, professional development opportunities, and community-building activities.  One example was the signature BSN event, the BSN Deep Dive, which was held annually in 2015-2017. This event offered a unique gathering of MPS academic and professional scientists and students. It was designed to inspire and advance student participants and make the Berkeley science community a more diverse, inclusive, and enjoyable place to engage in learning and scientific discovery. Students evaluated these events as achieving these goals. BSN-LP scholars also were made aware of valuable opportunities for engagement in research, applicable conferences, and other events relevant to their educational success and retention in STEM fields.

BROADER IMPACTS

Of the 51 students supported by BSN-LP, 39 (76%) scholars graduated with 31 (60%) scholars graduating in STEM fields. Of these, 23 scholars (45%) graduated in the mathematical, physical, and computer sciences majors. Of the remaining 12 BSN-LP scholars, seven (15%) remain enrolled with six (13%) continuing in STEM majors; five (9%) BSN-LP scholars are no longer enrolled and did not graduate. BSN-LP scholars graduated with a cumulative 3.2 GPA average.  The BSN-LP Scholars in the earliest cohorts --freshmen entrants in 2014 and 2015-- also offer an opportunity to assess the persistence to degree of the BSN-LP scholars in the mathematical and physical sciences, specifically. A total of 27 first and second year students were supported by BSN-LP in this period. Of these participants,14 intended majors in the math and physical sciences disciplines. Of these 14 intended MPS majors, 10 (71%) both declared a MPS major and received a degree in MPS. Of the 14 participants who intended MPS majors, 11 participants were from underrepresented groups. Of these 11 URM participants,  seven (64%) both declared and received a degree in MPS. These are higher rates of persistence to MPS degree than was typical in this period, when overall persistence to degrees with a MPS major was 53% and persistence to degrees for URMs in MPS was 40%.
